title: Abdullah I of Jordan
summary: Abdullah I bin Al-Hussein (Arabic: عبد الله الأول بن الحسين‎, Abd Allāh el-Awwal ibn el-Hüseyn, 2 February 1882 – 20 July 1951) was the founder and ruler of the Jordanian realm from 11 April 1921 until his assassination on the 20th of July 1951. He was the Emir of Transjordan, a British protectorate, until 25 May 1946,[1][2] after which he was the king of an independent Jordan. As a member of the Hashemite dynasty, the royal family of Transjordan/Jordan since 1921, Abdullah was a 38th-generation direct descendant of Muhammad.[5]
